children.name: happening all the time, without stopping or changing
always
children.definition: /ˈɔːlwɪz, ˈɔːlwəz, -weɪz/  all the time without changing:
examples: ▪ the temperature of the lake is always below fifty-five degrees.
▪ ron is always in a bad mood in the morning.
▪ our upstairs neighbor always keeps to himself. we hardly know him at all.

children.name: all the time
children.definition: /ˌɔːl ðə ˈtaɪm/
examples: ▪ gabrielle talks about her kids all the time.
▪ the couple upstairs argue all the time.
▪ i don’t have to wear my glasses all the time - just for reading.

children.name: the whole time
children.definition: /ðə ˌhəʊl ˈtaɪm/  all the time while something is happening - use this about somethingannoyingorsurprising:
examples: mọi lúc , cứ lúc nào ...
▪ he talked about himself the whole time i was with him.
▪ we realized that duncan had been standing there the whole time.

children.name: at all times
children.definition: /ət ˌɔːl ˈtaɪmz/  all the time - used especially inofficialnotices and rules:
examples: luôn luôn
▪ carry your passport with you at all times.
▪ keep your hotel door locked at all times.

children.name: constantly b2
children.definition: constantly/ˈkɒnstəntliǁˈkɑːn-/  all the time, continuously:
examples: luôn luôn
▪ shelly constantly tries to impress her boss.
▪ she constantly criticizes my cooking.
constant[adjective]
▪ the patient must be kept under constant supervision.
▪ the rains are constant in winter.

children.name: permanently b2
children.definition: permanently/ˈpɜːʳmənəntli/  all the time and never likely to change: luôn luôn
examples: ▪ hardy was permanently banned from professional figure skating.
▪ it’s such a dangerous neighborhood that the windows of some stores are permanently barricaded.
permanent[adjective]
▪ the country seems to be in a permanent state of crisis.

children.name: perennial
children.definition: /pəˈreniəl/  perennial problem/concern/struggle etc one which people are concerned with all the time, and have been concerned with for a long time:
examples: muôn thuở, nan giải
▪ high unemployment rates are a perennial problem in several european countries.
▪ severe and unpredictable weather is a perennial danger for mountain climbers.

children.name: unfailing
children.definition: /ʌnˈfeɪlɪŋ/  unfailing support/loyalty/good humour etc support, loyalty etc that you can depend on because it never changes or grows weaker even when there is trouble or difficulty:
examples: không bao giờ cạn
▪ i’d like to thank you all for your unfailing love and support.
▪ peter’s unfailing humour made him popular with his fellow workers.

children.name: incessant
children.definition: /ɪnˈsesənt/ happening or done all the time without stopping, in a way that is veryannoying:
examples: liên miên ko ngớt
▪ julia became irritated by the child’s incessant talking.
▪ the incessant buzz of conversation filled the student cafeteria.
incessantly[adverb]
▪ michael smokes incessantly.

children.name: day in, day out
children.definition: /deɪ ˌɪn, deɪ ˈaʊt/ every day for a long time - use this especially to say that someone keeps doing somethingdifficult,tiring, orboringfor a long time, or that something keeps happening for a long time:
examples: ngày này qua ngày khác
▪ henry did the same thing, day in and day out, for over thirty years.
▪ investigators are working day in, day out to determine the cause of the crash.

children.name: morning, noon, and night
children.definition: morning,noon,andnight/ˌmɔːnɪŋ ˌnuːn ən ˈnaɪt/ spoken said in order to emphasize that something happens all the time, especially something that isannoying:
examples: sáng trưa tối
▪ it seems like we’ve been going to meetings morning, noon, and night lately.

children.definition: /ˌtwentifɔːʳ ˈsevən/ informalall the time without stopping:
examples: ▪ we’re here to help you 24/7.
▪ the deadline is next week, so everyone in the office is working 24/7.

children.name: often a1
children.definition: often/ˈɒfən, ˈɒftənǁˈɔːf-/
examples: ▪ i often see her walking past with the children on the way to school.
▪ dad wasn’t often angry so i knew something terrible must have happened.quite often
▪ ‘have you ever been to the china moon café?’ ‘yes -- we go there quite often.’not very often
▪ i have a cell phone, but i don’t use it very often.it’s not often (that) somebody does something
▪ it’s not often that you see a grass snake these days -- they’ve become quite rare.
▪ it’s not often i get the chance to go to the movies.

children.name: a lot a1
children.definition: a lot/ə ˈlɒtǁ-ˈlɑːt/  spoken if you do something a lot, you often do it:
examples: ▪ it’s nice to meet you. wendy’s talked about you a lot.
▪ i used to walk a lot, but i’ve been very lazy recently.quite a lot british
▪ she goes abroad on business quite a lot.

children.name: tend to do sth b2
children.definition: tend to do something to often do a particular thing, and be likely to do it:
examples: ▪ dave tends to arrive late, so don’t worry yet.
▪ the problem with this model of car is that the gearbox tends to seize up.
▪ my father tends to interfere too much in other people’s business.
▪ recent studies show that girls tend to be better at languages than boys.

children.name: frequently b1
children.definition: frequently/ˈfriːkwəntli/  often - used especially in writing or more formal speech:
examples: ▪ passengers complain that trains are frequently cancelled.
▪ you have to be willing to change jobs frequently if you want to get to the top in business.
▪ frequently, she would find herself gazing out of the window lost in thought.

children.name: repeatedly c1
children.definition: repeatedly use this to emphasize that someone did something many times:
examples: ▪ graham’s doctor had repeatedly warned him not to work so hard.
▪ max was punched and kicked repeatedly as he lay on the ground.
▪ al gore has stated repeatedly, that the american economy is dependent upon a healthy environment.

children.name: again and again b1
children.definition: again and again/əˌgen ənd əˈgen/  use this to emphasize that the same thing has happened many times:
examples: ▪ she kept asking the same question again and again.
▪ again and again i was thrown upwards from my bunk as the ship battled through the storm.

children.name: hundreds of times u
children.definition: hundreds/thousands oftimes spoken say this when you are emphasizing that sb has done sth many times in the past: cả trăm, cả ngàn lần
examples: it was a sound he’d heard thousands of times before.
my grandmother must have spoken to him hundreds of times but, surprisingly, she didn’t know his name.
i’ve been rejected hundreds of times, but if you don’t try you never will get a job, will you?

children.name: many times u
children.definition: many times if sb has done sth many times, they have done it often:nhiều lần
examples: sb has/had done sth many times (before)
▪ i had walked down this road many times before, but somehow today it seemed different.
as sb has/had done many times (before)
▪ the woman upstairs shouted down at us and threatened to call the police, as she had done many times before.
▪ i looked down at the town, as i had done so many times as a young man, and remembered the people i had known there.

children.name: too often, in a way that is annoying
keep (on) doing sth
children.definition: /ˌkiːp (ɒn) ˈduːɪŋ something/  especially spoken to do something many times, in a way that is annoying:
examples: cứ ...
▪ dad, bobby keeps hitting me!
▪ how can i explain if you keep on interrupting me?
▪ i keep forgetting to mail this letter.

children.name: always/all the time
children.definition: /ˈɔːlwɪz, ˈɔːlwəz, ˌɔːl ðə ˈtaɪm/  if someone or something is always doing something, or someone or something does something all the time, it annoys you because they do it too often :
examples: ▪ i’m sick of harold, he’s always telling me what to do.
▪ what do you mean you never see me? you’re at my house all the time.
▪ i don’t know about you, but i’m always having arguments with people!
▪ he was always trying to persuade me to go out drinking with him.

children.name: constantly/continually
children.definition: /ˈkɒnstəntliǁˈkɑːn-, kənˈtɪnjuəli/  use this when you are very annoyed because something happens repeatedly over a long period of time:
examples: ▪ they seemed to be continually arguing.
▪ i wish you’d clean up your room without having to be constantly reminded.

children.name: ad nauseam x
children.definition: ad nauseam/ˌædˈnɔːziəm, -iæm/  if someone talks about something ad nauseam, they talk about it for so long that it becomes veryannoyingorboring:
examples: đến nỗi phát ngán
▪ we’ve discussed this ad nauseam, and i don’t see the point of going over the same ground again.
▪ he goes on ad nauseam about how much better everything was in the old days.

children.name: with great regularity
children.definition: /wɪð ˌgreɪt regjɑˈlærti/  if something happens with great regularity, it keeps happening, often in an annoying way:
examples: ▪ yes, the bank keep piling these outrageous charges on my bank account with great regularity.
▪ with great regularity, wasps would fly in through the open window and get trapped behind the glass.

children.name: time and time again x
children.definition: time and time again/ˌtaɪm ən taɪm əˈgen/  use this to say that something has been done many times, especially when this is annoying or does not have any effect: hết lần này đến lần khác
examples: ▪ i’ve told you time and time again not to play with matches - it’s dangerous.
▪ i see people making the same mistakes, time and time again.

children.name: half the time u
children.definition: half the time/ˈhɑːf ðə ˌtaɪmǁˈhæf-/ spokensay this when you are describing somethingannoyingorbadthat someone does very often:
examples: ▪ half the time the managers don’t know what’s going on.
▪ i never know where he is - half the time he doesn’t return my phone calls.

children.name: be forever doing st
children.definition: be forever doing something/biː fərˌevəʳ ˈduːɪŋ something/  spoken if someone or something is forever doing something, they annoy you by doing it very often over a long period of time:
examples: cứ làm mãi
▪ he never does his homework on time and is forever getting into trouble at school.
▪ we bought a new washing machine. the old one was forever breaking down.

children.name: during the whole of an event or period of time
all the time a2
children.definition: all the time/ˌɔːl ðə ˈtaɪm/  all the time (that)
examples: mọi lúc
▪ i couldn’t really enjoy my holiday because i was sick all the time i was there.
▪ all the time i was talking to him he just sat and stared at the television.

children.name: throughout b2/ all through
children.definition: throughout/all through/θruːˈaʊt, ˈɔːl θruː/  during all of a particular period of time, especially when this is a long time:
examples: suốt
▪ lester was sickly all through his childhood.
▪ yvonne lived in switzerland throughout the war.

children.name: all day long
children.definition: all day/night/summer etc long/ˌɔːl deɪ ˈlɒŋ ǁ-ˈlɔːŋ/  during all of the day, night, summer etc:
examples: ▪ it often rains here all day long.
▪ the music coming from the apartment upstairs kept me awake all night long.

children.name: all along b2
children.definition: all along/ɔːl əˈlɒŋǁ-əˈlɔːŋ/  if a particular situation hasexistedall along, it has existed all the time right from the beginning, although you may not have known about it:
examples: ngay từ đầu
▪ i spent over an hour looking for my keys, and they were in my purse all along.
be right all along
▪ he realized that she’d been right all along.

children.name: from start to finish
children.definition: /from beginning to end/frəm ˌstɑːʳt tə ˈfɪnɪʃ, frəm bɪˌgɪŋɪŋ tʊ ˈend/  if an event or something that you do isgood,badetcfrom start to finish, it is like that from the time it begins until it ends:
examples: từ đầu đến cuối
▪ it was an awful day at work - problems from start to finish.
▪ the whole thing was a disaster from beginning to end.

children.name: frequent b1
children.definition: frequent/ˈfriːkwənt/
examples: thường xuyên
▪ his job involved making frequent trips to saudi arabia.
▪ the doctor recommended frequent salt baths to help the wound heal.
▪ my duties brought me into frequent contact with captain nagumo.
▪ as the treatment began to take effect, her headaches became less frequent.
frequent visitor/traveller/flier etc
someone who visits, uses something etc frequently
▪ as a frequent business traveler, i have spent many nights in bland hotel rooms.
▪ simmons is a frequent guest on daytime tv talk shows.

children.name: repeated c2
children.definition: repeated/rɪˈpiːtɪd, rɪˈpiːtəd/  repeated actions are done on several occasions, especially because they do not have any effect at first:
examples: liên tiếp , lặp đi lặp lại
▪ the torture involved repeated beatings and electric shock treatment.
▪ there have been repeated requests for the united nations to send peace-keeping forces to the area.
▪ massieu remains a free man, despite repeated attempts to arrest him on murder and drug charges.

children.name: habitual x
children.definition: habitual/həˈbɪtʃuəl/  done often as a habit, especially when this is annoying to other people:
examples: quen thói
▪ ingrained attitudes and habitual ways of thinking are very difficult to change.
▪ tony’s habitual laziness became even more extreme in winter, and he would sometimes stay in bed until mid afternoon.:
habitual drinker/gambler/drug user/offender/felon etcsomeone who does something bad or illegal
▪ my father was a habitual gambler, until my mother packed her bags and threatened to leave.
▪ it is estimated that as many as half the young men in the community are habitual drug users.
habitually[adverb]
▪ bernstein habitually arrived at airports just moments before departure.

children.name: continual c1
children.definition: continual/constant/kənˈtɪnjuəl, ˈkɒnstəntǁˈkɑːn-/  use this about things thatannoyyou because they happen repeatedly over a long time:
examples: liên tục
▪ it’s impossible to work with these constant interruptions.
▪ we’ve had continual problems with the computer system ever since it was installed.
